speaker: Martin
text: You got something on your mind?

speaker: Daphne
text: It's Joe.  Tonight's our six-month anniversary, but we can't celebrate until next week because he's flying to Las Vegas with his buddies.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, Vegas, huh?  Great!  Well, tell him not to miss the show at the Diamond Lounge: a Topless History of the World!  If they've still got the same Bathsheeba he's in for a real treat!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh yes, that's just where I want Joe spending our anniversary, some smutty show in Vegas!

speaker: Martin
text: No, it's very tasteful and historically accurate.  Except at the end, where Eleanor Roosevelt and Eva Braun settle World War Two by wrestling in pudding.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles.  To what do we owe this pleasure?

speaker: Niles
text: To an unscrupulous art dealer who's trying to rob me blind. Last night, I was at a gallery opening, and--

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, is this going to be a long story?

speaker: Niles
text: Moderately.

speaker: Frasier
text: Walk-and-talk.

speaker: Niles
text: Anyway, I was at this opening, in conversation, when I made a rather emphatic point about pointillism, when I lost the grip on my canape and found that it became airborne!  Well, the next thing I know I'm being confronted by an irate gallery owner who's demanding I reimburse him for the damage to one of his paintings!  How he could notice a fleck of foie gras on a Jackson Pollock is beyond me.

speaker: Niles
text: He's getting an estimate, and just to protect myself, I seem to recall you knowing a trustworthy art restorer?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yes, I do, actually.  Saved my life last year when Eddie licked my Liechtenstein!  I'll get you his card.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: You free for lunch today?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, sadly, no.  The radio station is subjecting my program to something they call a "focus group" this afternoon. Dinner, perhaps?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, perfect.  And what exactly is a focus group?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, they actually drag a pack of people off the street and make them listen to my program, and then dutifully record their opinions about it.

speaker: Niles
text: How demeaning!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, absolutely.  Can you imagine Sigmund Freud being dragged into a roomful of Viennese laymen to hear remarks like, "hate that Oedipal thing, but, oh, love the penis envy!" I mean, really!  The worst thing is that they may change my show in deference to the opinion of Joe Six-Pack!

speaker: Martin
text: You're worrying too much.  I was on a focus group once.

speaker: Frasier
text: That sound you hear is a nail being hammered into my coffin.

speaker: Martin
text: They were trying out a new frozen snack.  It was a meatball with the cheese injected right in the middle.

speaker: Frasier
text: Just as nature intended.

speaker: Niles
text: Dr. Niles Crane.  Ah.  So, you have the estimate?  What?  Four thousand dollars, to remove a miniscule gobbet of duck liver?! I could do the same thing with a Q-tip and some club seltzer! Oh well, you may very well say "pay up or else," but I have something to say to you--  _The art dealer hangs up on him.  Behind his back, Daphne turns on the television to a daytime talk show._

speaker: Woman
text: **[_on TV_] Yeah, well at least I wasn't fooling around with the babysitter!

speaker: Man
text: [_on TV_] Shut up!

speaker: Woman
text: ** No, you shut up!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh please, I have enough aggravation without having to listen to a stupid talk show!  I swear, the only life forms lower than the people who appear on those shows are the ones who watch them!

speaker: Daphne
text: Like me?

speaker: Niles
text: What? [_sees her_] Oh no, I didn't realize--

speaker: Daphne
text: No, no, no, that's quite all right.  Although I do find it interesting that I get criticized for listening to people's problems, when all you do is get rich from it.

speaker: Niles
text: Surely, Daphne, even you can see the difference between cheap sensationalism and the practice of psychiatry.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, "even me?"  As in, "even feeble-minded Daphne?!"  Well, I'll tell you what I can tell the difference between: a true gentleman and a condescending prig!

speaker: Niles
text: [_flabbergasted_] I... am NOT!

speaker: Daphne
text: He said priggishly.  _Niles throws down his phone.  Undying adoration and worship are all well and good, but this is WAR!_

speaker: Niles
text: Forgive me if I'm not as down to earth as you and your tattooed, muu-muu wearing brethren!

speaker: Daphne
text: You pompous twit!

speaker: Niles
text: Couch zombie!

speaker: Daphne
text: Snob!

speaker: Niles
text: Brat!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, shut up!

speaker: Niles
text: No, YOU shut up!

speaker: Martin
text: I'm glad we turned off the TV.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, Dr. Crane, I'm so sorry!  I'm just so upset at Joe! I didn't mean a word of it!

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne, I apologize--

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh no, it was my fault--

speaker: Niles
text: I called you a couch zombie--

speaker: Daphne
text: No, please--

speaker: Niles
text: [_offers hand_] Friends?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_shaking_] Oh, of course. _She goes to the kitchen, laughing with relief.  Niles just stands there, shell-shocked.  Frasier comes out._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, what was that all about?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm not sure.  But, oh, mama, it was glorious!  Blood- pounding, sarcastic zingers flying!

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you saying you that enjoyed fighting with Daphne?

speaker: Niles
text: Every exhilarating moment!  It was pure, unbridled passion! I think I still have some of her spittle on my forehead! Oh, why did Dad ever tell us not to fight with girls? It's wonderful!  The friction between us--

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, is this going to be a long description?

speaker: Niles
text: Very!

speaker: Frasier
text: Walk-and-talk.  _They go out the door, Niles continue to wax rhapsodic.  FADE OUT  Scene Two -- Conference Room A dozen average-looking people are seated around a long table. In the middle is a tape recorder.  On one wall is a two-way mirror._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_on tape_] By showering a reluctant girlfriend with gifts, Billy, you're applying a band-aid to a gaping wound.  My advice is to find someone who will return your worthy affection, or your wallet, as well as your bed, will be empty.  I see we're out of time.  Thank you for listening. This is Dr. Frasier Crane, wishing you all good mental health.

speaker: Moderator
text: OK, let's talk about Dr. Crane's show.  Oh, I know you've been eyeing this two-way mirror, but the other people behind there are data consultants, so please speak freely.  There's no one involved with the show whose feelings could be hurt.  _On the other side, Frasier and Roz are watching, along with a data collector with a clipboard._

speaker: Roz
text: If anybody says anything bad about me, I'll kill myself!

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, Roz, relax.  We do a perfectly good show.  We're not going to change it one iota.  Only a fool would listen to the opinion of every Tom, Dick, and Harry.

speaker: Man 1
text: I liked everything about it.

speaker: Frasier
text: On the other hand, it's good to keep an open mind.

speaker: Man 2
text: I like that Roz.  I think her voice is really sexy, especially that throaty laugh of hers.

speaker: Roz
text: Wow, that's nice.  I didn't know I had a throaty laugh.

speaker: Collector
text: You do.  I've noticed it too.

speaker: Roz
text: Really?  Oh, you. [_throaty laugh_]

speaker: Man 2
text: The stuff he says really seems to make a lot of sense.

speaker: Woman 1
text: ** Yeah, it's funny.  I mean, he takes his callers seriously, but he can kid around with them too.

speaker: Woman 2
text: Yeah, I listen to a lot of radio, and I think this is a great show.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I just don't know how much more of this I can listen to!

speaker: Moderator
text: Manu, I notice you've been quiet.  Uh, do you have something to say?

speaker: Manu
text: Me?  No.

speaker: Moderator
text: We'd like to hear your opinion of the program.

speaker: Manu
text: Well, it... I don't know.  Something about... I don't like it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, who is this cheeky nonconformist?

speaker: Collector
text: [_checks clipboard_] Well, let's see, his name is Manu Habib, married, no children, owns his own newsstand.

speaker: Roz
text: Wow, that is so weird, to hear someone's whole life summed up like that.  "Roz Doyle, Radio Producer, single." [_throaty laugh_]

speaker: Moderator
text: Well, getting back to your thoughts, Manu, you said there was something about the program you didn't like.  Can you be more specific.

speaker: Manu
text: I don't like him.

speaker: Moderator
text: Why?

speaker: Manu
text: I don't know.  I just don't like him.

speaker: Man 2
text: Oh, I do.  I'm gonna start listening to him all the time.

speaker: Woman 1
text: It's a great show.

speaker: Roz
text: My God, Frasier, this is a love-fest!  I can't believe we were even worried about it.

speaker: Frasier
text: "I just don't like him."  Hmm...

speaker: Moderator
text: Well, looks like our coffee's here.  Why don't we take a quick break, OK?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Hey, sports fans!  How's it going in here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Bulldog, I thought they were testing your show across the hall?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Oh, yeah, they are.  But after ten minutes it's just the same-old, same-old.  Guys love me, chicks pretend not to. Whoa, your group's even uglier than mine!

speaker: Roz
text: Would you knock it off?  These people happen to like us.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Oh, will you guys lighten up?  You got to get in the spirit of things.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Hey, hey!  This is great, I live for a moment like this.  _The man sticks a finger in his teeth.  Frasier, Roz, and the consultant look disgusted._

speaker: Bulldog
text: That's right, that's right, go for it, right there, right there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Bulldog--

speaker: Bulldog
text: As long as you're in there you might as well go after the Huevos Rancheros you had for breakfast!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, stop it!

speaker: Bulldog
text: Hey, ten bucks says he eats what he finds.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's disgusting!

speaker: Bulldog
text: Come on, come on, come on, come on-- [_the man puts the finger back in his mouth_] BINGO!  Do I know these people or what?! _Frasier, Roz, and the consultant all make disgusted faces and shoo him out.  FADE TO:_  _Scene Three -- Apartment The doorbell rings.  Martin opens the door to Niles._

speaker: Martin
text: Hi, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, Dad.  May I assume from your dress windbreaker that you'll be joining us for dinner?

speaker: Martin
text: Yep, but I'm making a pitch that we eat at the Timber Mill. I got a coupon from there that expires tomorrow.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh.  If I dine there tonight, so may I.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, there's the British bobcat!

speaker: Martin
text: Now, look, she's still a little bit over the edge about this Joe thing.  So you better watch your step or you're gonna have a repeat of this morning.

speaker: Niles
text: We wouldn't want that, would we?  Chips, Daphne?  Was that wise?

speaker: Daphne
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Niles
text: You know what they say, "many chips make for chunky hips." Waddle, waddle, waddle!

speaker: Martin
text: Have you lost your mind?!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, no, no, I'm glad if I put on a few pounds.  Now maybe Joe will stop nagging me to plump up! _Niles is disappointed as his first salvo backfires.  Frasier comes in._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Fras, how was the focus group?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sulky_] Fine, I guess.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, well, you said yourself they didn't mean anything.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, it's one thing to say that.  It's another to sit there being personally attacked!  One man actually said, [_with great weight_] "I just don't like him."

speaker: Niles
text: Only one?

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm sure someone must have said something nice.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, all the other eleven had nothing but high praise.

speaker: Martin
text: Eleven out of twelve liked you?  You should be thrilled! F..DR didn't have that kind of approval rating.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, or Churchill for that matter.

speaker: Niles
text: Churchill--that cigar-chomping gin blossom with a face attached!

speaker: Daphne
text: You're right about that.  There's a kiss hello to put you off your tea.

speaker: Frasier
text: I wish I was able to talk to this man and ask him what it is about me that he doesn't like.  But, I-I can't, you see, he was told that his comments would be kept confidential.

speaker: Martin
text: Just forget it.  Come on, let's go out to dinner.  I'm buying.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, what is it he doesn't like about me?  My voice, my manner, do I intimidate him?

speaker: Martin
text: I don't know!  What is it about you?  Everybody has to love you!  Just like when you were in that play in high school. You get standing ovations every night, all your friends say you're great, you got one lousy review in the school paper and you sulked for a week.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, Dad, I'd like to think I've matured a bit since then.  But, you know, you would have sulked too, if you'd read in the paper, "Mr. Crane's attempts to gyrate his hips as Conrad, the teen idol in 'Bye-Bye, Birdie,' made this reviewer say, 'Bye-bye, breakfast!'"

speaker: Niles
text: That review was a mash note compared to my first draft.

speaker: Daphne
text: I know just what you're going through.  I once won a dance competition hands down, but instead of celebrating I spent the whole night fretting over my one bad score. [_laughs_] Silly-head!

speaker: Niles
text: Idiot.

speaker: Niles
text: [_at last_] Oh, I've stepped in it now!

speaker: Daphne
text: Listen here, Dr. Crane--

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah, Daphne?

speaker: Frasier
text: All right now, Daphne, just a moment!  Just try to remember what you're like when you're arguing with Joe.  Consider Niles's situation.  He's separated.  You can't imagine the emotional see-saw he's on.  Not to mention the fact that he may be unaware that he's acting like a complete jackass!

speaker: Daphne
text: Of course, you're right.  I'm sorry, I should be more sensitive.  From now on, nothing you say can make me cross with you.

speaker: Niles
text: I suppose I had that coming.  Though I think "jackass" was a tad over the line.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, just consider it payback for the headline, "Crane's 'Birdie' Lays An Egg!"

speaker: Martin
text: All right, now, Fras, you got to let it go.  You know, no matter who you are, no matter what you do, you can't please everyone.

speaker: Frasier
text: I suppose my negative baggage is just a pound or two over the weight limit.

speaker: Martin
text: O.K., good, come on, let's go have dinner.

speaker: Frasier
text: This is good!  This is healthy!  I'm letting go! _FADE TO:  Scene Four -- Street Frasier is driving with Martin and Niles.  Suddenly he pulls over. Across the street is a newsstand, manned by Manu._

speaker: Frasier
text: There he is.  The man who... doesn't like me.

speaker: Martin
text: I knew we should have taken two cars.  _END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO_  **LIAR, LIAR, PANTS ON FIRE**

speaker: Martin
text: What are we doing here?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, Dad.  It's just that "I just don't like him," it's not specific enough.  Why doesn't he like me?

speaker: Martin
text: What difference does it make?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, if his point was valid, I would do something about it. If it's not, well, then I could dismiss it.

speaker: Martin
text: Fine, go talk to him.

speaker: Frasier
text: I can't.  He's not supposed to know I was part of the focus group.  You, Dad!  You could go talk to him for me.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, for crying out loud--

speaker: Niles
text: Look, if we're going to be here for a while, could we at least lock the doors?

speaker: Martin
text: Relax, Niles, the neighborhood's O.K.

speaker: Niles
text: The docks are two blocks from here!

speaker: Martin
text: So's the Ritz-Carleton.

speaker: Niles
text: Exactly!  We're caught halfway between heaven and hell.

speaker: Frasier
text: All I want is more information.  Dad, please?  Please go talk to him for me?

speaker: Martin
text: All right, if I get an answer for you, can we go to dinner?

speaker: Frasier
text: O.K., fine. [_Martin opens his door_] Oh, but wait, wait, wait!  Now you can't just walk up there and ask him.  He'll know that I sent you.  Got to find some artful way of introducing the subject.

speaker: Niles
text: Can we at least hide Dad's handicapped sign?  It sends a clear signal that we're incapable of fighting back!

speaker: Martin
text: So do your suspenders.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, I've got it, I've got it.  You're a business man in town from Chicago.  No, no, it's too obvious.  Uh, from Cleveland.  No would ever pretend to be from Cleveland.

speaker: Martin
text: Fine, then we eat. [_starts to get out_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Wait, wait, we're not through yet!  Yes, you've had a bad sales month, and you're a little depressed.  You happen to see an add for my show on the side of a bus, and you were wondering if I'm as intelligent as I look.

speaker: Martin
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, just word it your own way.  Are we clear on this now?

speaker: Martin
text: All right, I got it.  Businessman, Cleveland, depressed, then eat!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Dad, eat!  Honestly, sometimes you can get so obsessed about things!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, God, it's raining!

speaker: Martin
text: Hi, I'm Marty Crane.  My son's Dr. Frasier Crane.  He's across the street in that BMW. [_Manu looks_] No, don't look!

speaker: Manu
text: Oh, my God.  He was behind the mirror.

speaker: Martin
text: Look, don't worry about it.  He's not mad at you.  He just want to know why you don't like him.

speaker: Manu
text: But I do like him.

speaker: Martin
text: No, you don't.

speaker: Manu
text: Oh, yes, I do!

speaker: Martin
text: No, he heard what you said.

speaker: Manu
text: I can't do this.  I don't like to say bad things about people, and you are his father--

speaker: Martin
text: No, you'd be doing me a favor!  Just answer this one question, and we'll all get out of your life forever.

speaker: Manu
text: All right.  I-I don't know your son well.  But, uh, I guess I find him, uh, just a little bit... annoying.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah?

speaker: Manu
text: Annoying.

speaker: Martin
text: O.K.  You did good.  Thanks.

speaker: Manu
text: Please tell your son I'm sorry that he annoys me so much.

speaker: Martin
text: Will do.

speaker: Niles
text: Not yet... not yet... not yet. [_Martin reaches the door_] OK, unlock! [_Frasier unlocks the doors; Martin gets in_] And lock! [_Frasier locks_]

speaker: Martin
text: Mission accomplished.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good.  Did he believe my story?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yeah, I had him going pretty good.  That Cleveland thing really sold it.  Well, we better go eat now, huh?  Before he sees us again.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right. [_starts car_] So, uh, Dad, what doesn't he like about me?

speaker: Martin
text: He said you annoy him.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, how so?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I didn't ask him.

speaker: Frasier
text: What do you mean you didn't ask him?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, geez!

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, Dad, but I have no idea what "he's annoying" means!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, it's clear enough to me!

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm just going to have to do this myself!

speaker: Martin
text: Here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.

speaker: Martin
text: Who're you calling?

speaker: Niles
text: No one.  I just pressed 911, and I'm keeping my finger poised over the Send button in case there's trouble with those hooligans. [_points out the window_]

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, the UPS men or the little girls playing in the puddle?

speaker: Manu
text: Hello.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello.

speaker: Manu
text: I can help you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh, yes, yes, you were recently speaking with a salesman from Cleveland.

speaker: Manu
text: I don't think so.

speaker: Frasier
text: It was just five minutes ago.  He left you and went over to that car waiting right over there.  You see?  _He points over his shoulder to the BMW, where Martin and Niles are now both staring at him._

speaker: Manu
text: Oh, God, no.  You're him, it's you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, it is.  I'm so sorry, I really don't mean to bother you but I would like to talk to you for a minute.

speaker: Manu
text: I like your show.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no.

speaker: Manu
text: I like your show, and I like you.

speaker: Frasier
text: That man was my father--

speaker: Manu
text: I like your father!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's very nice of you, but you see, you told him that, uh, you find me annoying. [_Manu protests_] Yes, yes, you did, and that's all right.  I don't mind constructive criticism. It's just that I wish you could be a bit more specific. What exactly is it about me that you find so annoying?

speaker: Manu
text: You're not annoying.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I am!  Would I be here if I wasn't?

speaker: Manu
text: Well, I have enjoyed talking to you very much, but it's time for my break.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no, no, please!  _Manu reaches up to the metal curtain.  Frasier leans forward to stop him, knocking a bottle of Yoo-Hoo over Manu's pants._

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm so sorry.

speaker: Manu
text: I am a sticky mess.

speaker: Frasier
text: Let me help you with that.

speaker: Manu
text: No, no, no, no, it's fine, good.

speaker: Frasier
text: Manu?

speaker: Manu
text: Drive safe.  _He pulls the curtain down to hide his face.  Frasier knocks on the curtain, causing it to plummet down, crushing Manu's hand.  Manu screams in pain._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear God!  I'm so sorry!  Are you all right?  Let me look at it, let me look at it--

speaker: Manu
text: No, no!

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, I am a doctor.

speaker: Manu
text: No, no, I just go to the restaurant to put ice on it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right, you know, I'll hold down the fort here!  Glad to be of help!

speaker: Niles
text: [_matter-of-fact_] He's crushed the gentleman's hand, and now he appears to be commandeering his newsstand.

speaker: Martin
text: Uh-huh.  _Frasier steps into the newsstand.  He notices a smoldering cigar sitting in an ashtray._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, good lord.  Smoking in the worst places!

speaker: Amanda
text: How much for the paper?

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, yes, uh, well, that would be [_checks the paper_] oh, fifty cents. [_she pays_] Thank you so much.  There we are.

speaker: Amanda
text: Scuse me, are you Dr. Crane from the radio?

speaker: Frasier
text: Why, yes, I am.

speaker: Amanda
text: Oh, I just never miss your show!  I love you!  I guess you get tired of hearing that.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, occupational hazard.

speaker: Amanda
text: [_takes out paper and pen_] Oh, would you mind--?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I wouldn't mind at all.

speaker: Amanda
text: To Amanda.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_autographs paper_] Amanda, it's a pleasure.

speaker: Amanda
text: What are you doing here, anyway?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, oh, well you see, let me explain, you see. [_steps out of the newsstand_] The, uh, radio station conducted a little audio survey today, and although the response was favorable from eleven out of twelve of the participants--

speaker: Amanda
text: Is that smoking?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_oblivious_] Well, some people might consider it smoking, but you see, for me--

speaker: Amanda
text: FIRE!  _Amanda runs away.  Frasier, yelling for help, does the same.  In the car, Niles's face is now resting on his hand.  Martin, face still covered, is sunk even lower in his seat._

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, my God.  Frasier set his newsstand on fire.

speaker: Martin
text: Mmm-hmm. _FADE TO:  Scene Six -- Street As firemen probe through the charred ruins of the newsstand, Manu sits on the sidewalk with his head in his hands [_one bandaged_]. Frasier comes over._

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh, may I? [_sits beside him_] Look, I know there's nothing I can say right now that would make you feel any better, but rest assured, I will be financially responsible for everything.

speaker: Manu
text: All this because you had to know why I do not like you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you were kind of vague.

speaker: Manu
text: You want to know why?  I'll tell you why.  I think you are a smarty-pants.  I was too polite to say that before.  But then you spied on me, you stalked me, you badgered me, you poured Yoo-Hoo down my Dockers, you crunched my hand, and then, as if all that was not enough, you burned down my newsstand, my livelihood, a gift to me from my beloved uncle, may he rest in peace!

speaker: Frasier
text: Was that so hard?  _Frasier leaves.  END OF ACT TWO_
